image.altText: Collage of three masked faces, one with a balaclava, another with a wrestling mask. They are cut by three lines of cocaine.

items.synopsis: Australians are the biggest consumers of cocaine in the world, and we pay top dollar for it. For the first time, three dealers lift the lid on this booming industry.

title.children: 'We've sold to football players, lawyers, celebrities on TV': Cocaine dealers break their code of silence

image.altText: A selfie of a man wearing a beanie while on Mount Everest

items.synopsis: Australian man Jason Kennison dies while descending Mount Everest, a climb he had undertaken to raise money for Spinal Cord Injuries Australia.

title.children: Australian man dies during Mount Everest climb

image.altText: Woman with dark curly shoulder length hair and light brown skin sits in front of a laptop in an office late at night

items.synopsis: Many Australians work very long hours, compared to other similar nations. This can lead to a poor work-life balance and a constant feeling of being time poor.

title.children: Unpaid overtime is an issue across all industries. Here's why it's such a problem

image.altText: A woman sitting on a bench near a road, looking on.

items.synopsis: Doctors told Lindy Bok she had two years to live. The psychedelic compound found in "magic mushrooms" is helping her face death, and get "20 years of therapy in one hit".

title.children: 'Really, mum, you're going to take drugs?': Lindy is dying, so she leaned in to life

image.altText: Vinu, Akila and their two children taking a selfie, smiling and pulling faces, shot from below with green foliage behind them

items.synopsis: Last year, the ABC issued a call-out asking readers to share their stories about how they were coping with rising interest rates and prices for everyday goods and services. Here's what some of them say they are doing now, nearly 12 months later, to make ends meet.

title.children: 'All I could do was cry': Australians reveal how they're dealing with the cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: 5 people on a dark background. There are five circles below them: green, grey, orange, yellow and red

items.synopsis: Use the ABC's Promise Tracker to check in on the government's progress over its first year.

title.children: Promise tracker: The Labor government's 2022 election commitments

image.altText: A SpaceX rocket flying upwards to space, with flames coming out of its bottom. Speed dials from a live stream.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happened.

title.children: Treasurer backs Stan Grant on racism, and SpaceX's latest private flight blasts off. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: a woman wearing glasses sitting down and holding an ipad showing a picture of an elderly woman

items.synopsis: The daughter of a woman with dementia who was handcuffed in a Sydney aged care home is demanding more accountability from police over instances of force being used against residents.

title.children: Daughter of elderly woman handcuffed say police have't learnt from past mistakes

image.altText: A woman holds an iPhone in her left hand showing the Afterpay name and logo.

items.synopsis: Buy now, pay later services, including Afterpay and Zip Pay, will be regulated under the Credit Act and required to obtain an Australian Credit Licence under proposed changes by the federal government.

title.children: Buy now, pay later 'looks like' and 'acts like' credit — now it will be regulated like it

image.altText: woman at desk taking call for 1800 my options service

items.synopsis: Women's Health Victoria says about 40 per cent of callers to 1800 My Options are unable to afford sexual and reproductive health services, including abortion.

title.children: Unexpectedly pregnant in a small town, Emily says an anonymous phone call made all the difference

image.altText: A woman holds her palm to her forehead as she stands in a corridor, silhouetted.

items.synopsis: A new survey has revealed that 45 per cent of 1,000 employees surveyed have felt overwhelmed by debt.

title.children: Mental wellbeing falls to levels last seen during COVID-19 lockdowns as cost-of-living pressure grows

image.altText: Aerial view shows destroyed multi-storey building with fire and smoke seen on some floors.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says its forces are still advancing around the edges of Bakhmut, aiming to encircle the ruined city, after Moscow congratulated the Wagner private army and Russian troops for capturing it.

title.children: Ukrainian troops aiming to encircle Bakhmut as Russia claims the ruined city

image.altText: a woman and a man holding a baby stand next to each other smiling on a beach, they are each holding a beer bottle

items.synopsis: The bodies of 26-year-old Jane Strong and 22-year-old Eli Johnson were found inside the burnt-out caravan. Ms Strong's partner was also injured in the blaze.

title.children: Community in shock after fatal caravan fire on rural southern Queensland property

image.altText: A bucket full of murky water in a shower.

items.synopsis: The EPA says it is concerned that Cadia Valley Operations is failing to meet its obligations following reports from residents that dust rising from its mine near Orange in NSW is contaminating their water and making their kids sick.

title.children: Gold mine to be probed after heavy metals found in residents' blood, rainwater

image.altText: A group hold a large banner saying 'logging is criminal in a climate emergency'

items.synopsis: Anti-logging activists have gathered in defiance of new Victorian laws that came into effect this weekend, saying the "draconian" legislation is criminalising peaceful protest.

title.children: Environmental activists gather to defy new 'anti-protest' laws in Victoria

image.altText: A Tesla parked next to a dark Volvo SUV near a green space.

items.synopsis: The council says electric vehicles need to be adopted rapidly, but other measures must be taken to cut down transport emissions.

title.children: EVs will help slash Australia's emissions but there are two more pressing problems to solve, Climate Council says

image.altText: Kate Andersson sitting at a table outside in May 2023

items.synopsis: Time is running out for millions of university graduates to slash their HECS debts before they increase by 7 per cent.

title.children: Students have just nine days to pay uni debt before indexation kicks in

image.altText: A young brown girl is adorned with gold, beaded jewellery and colourful sari. She is smiling confidently.

items.synopsis: From wanting to speak in an Aussie accent to comparing herself to others around her, Prarthana has learnt how to feel confident in her own skin.

title.children: 'My brown skin is beautiful': Prarthana's message for young girls trying to fit in

image.altText: Brooks Koepka smiles while leaning his arm on the Wanamaker Trophy

items.synopsis: Twelve months after the lowest point of his career, Brooks Koepka is a major champion again. Two things have changed to take him to the top of the mountain again — he got healthy, and he joined LIV Golf.

title.children: Brooks Koepka, a LIV golfer, just won the PGA Championship. Will it change the game?

image.altText: Saudi Arabian astronaut Rayyanah Barnawi waves to family and friends as she arrives at the Kennedy Space Center.

items.synopsis: The SpaceX rocket is carrying two Saudi and two American astronauts to the International Space Station on a Saudi-sponsored mission.

title.children: Saudi Arabia sends first woman to space on SpaceX-chartered mission

image.altText: A composite image of Zak Butters, Zach Merrett and Jy Simpkin

items.synopsis: A series of thrillers lit up the Sir Doug Nicholls Round, where classic finishes and controversy made for the best weekend of the 2023 season so far. We digest the week that was.

title.children: AFL Round-Up: Thrills and spills make Sir Doug Nicholls Round the best of the year so far

image.altText: Joe Biden and Anthony Albanese chatting

items.synopsis: Australian shares are set to lose ground after US debt ceiling talks fail to make progress in the absence of president Joe Biden. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to slip as US debt ceiling talks drag on

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some strong gains for coal miners and other energy companies are helping to minimise falls for the main ASX indices, while most other sectors trade in the red. Overall, the ASX 200 index was down 0.2% to 7,266 by 10:20am AEST, while the broader All Ords was off 17 points to 7,454 points. The energy sector was up 0.8% in early trade, with real estate the only other sector in the black (just). Education (-1%) and consumer cyclical firms (-0.5%) were the two weakest performers, with most stocks across the market posting only moderate moves. Top gains: BrainChip Holdings: +8.5% to $0.51 New Hope Corporation: +2.5% to $5.24 Kelsian Group: +2% to $6.70 West African Resources: +1.7% to $0.91 Viva Energy: +1.1% to $3.245 Biggest losses: Sayona Mining: -3.3% to $0.2225 Lovisa Holdings: -3.2% to $24.36 Fisher and Paykel Healthcare: -3.1% to $24.57 Allkem: -2.4% to $15.22 Metcash: -2.4% to $3.69
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy gains hold up ASX as other sectors ease

children.content: Some strong gains for coal miners and other energy companies are helping to minimise falls for the main ASX indices, while most other sectors trade in the red.
Overall, the ASX 200 index was down 0.2% to 7,266 by 10:20am AEST, while the broader All Ords was off 17 points to 7,454 points.
in early trade, with real estate the only other sector in the black (just).
were the two weakest performers, with most stocks across the market posting only moderate moves.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The PwC tax leaks scandal is far from over for the accountancy and consultancy partnership which used confidential information obtained while assisting the Australian government to draft new multinational tax laws to assist some of the multinationals targeted to plan strategies to legally minimise their tax bills under those laws. Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services Stephen Jones has told ABC business reporter Nassim Khadem that it's possible that the matter will be referred to the Australian Federal Police for potential criminal investigations. "We've got Treasury looking at an investigation into what has occurred, and looking at whether criminal charges should be referred to the AFP ," he said. "We're all appalled with what's gone on with PwC. We want to send a very clear message to them, and anyone else who's providing services to government, that you cannot breach the trust of the government or the Australian people. "So if criminal charges or other charges can be laid, we're looking forward to the outcomes of that investigation from Treasury." Nassim asked the minister whether the government might also hit PwC via its partners' hip pockets. "And so are you reviewing current government contracts [with PwC]?" "The Finance Minister and Treasury are looking at all of the options that are available to us," Mr Jones responded. The ABC's business editor Ian Verrender had some strong analysis last week on the PwC scandal.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Government considering possible criminal actions arising from PwC tax leaks scandal

featuredLink.title: Richard Boyle faces life behind bars while those in the PwC scandal are protected by the corporate world

children.content: is far from over for the accountancy and consultancy partnership which
obtained while assisting the Australian government to draft new multinational tax laws

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The NSW Environment Protection Authority (EPA) is launching an investigation into resident complaints of excessive dust coming from Newcrest's Cadia gold mine near Orange. Residents say testing has revealed high levels of some heavy metals, which they believe is coming from dust released by the mine. ABC journalists in the region, Joanna Woodburn and Micaela Hambrett are following the story.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Residents accuse Newcrest's Cadia gold mine of showering their properties in heavy metals

featuredLink.title: Gold mine to be probed after heavy metals found in residents' blood, rainwater

children.content: is launching an investigation into resident complaints of excessive dust coming from
Newcrest's Cadia gold mine near Orange
Residents say testing has revealed high levels of some heavy metals, which they believe is coming from dust released by the mine.

image.altText: G7 leaders line up for photo call by the seaside, with a Japanese mon (gate) seen in the water behind.

items.synopsis: The US president says the G7 nations have agreed a united approach to China that calls for diversifying supply chains and hinted he could speak with China's president soon.

title.children: G7 nations agree on united approach to China as Joe Biden aims for meeting with Xi Jinping

image.altText: A sign showing India's Prime Minster (right) and a photo sign of PNG's PM (left).

items.synopsis: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi lands in Port Moresby to host the third Forum for India-Pacific Islands Cooperation (FIPIC), which brings together leaders and top officials from New Delhi and 14 Pacific Island nations.

title.children: India's Modi lands in Papua New Guinea to host senior leaders at forum for India-Pacific Islands cooperation

image.altText: Older man with grey lond beard looks into the distance through glasses in a carport

items.synopsis: Pensioner Paul Bevington struggles to afford groceries, and he can't find a general practitioner who will bulk bill his medical appointments in his hometown of Alice Springs.

title.children: 'Is it going to kill me?': NT residents struggling without access to bulk billed medical services

image.altText: A man wearing white gloves is holding up the bottom of a Fender Stratocaster (guitar). It is signed in white.

items.synopsis: A guitar smashed on stage by Nirvana frontman Kurt Cobain sells for nearly $US600,000, almost 10 times its original estimate.

title.children: Guitar smashed by Nirvana's Kurt Cobain sells for nearly $900,000

image.altText: A woman in a blue football kit raises her arms in triumph.

items.synopsis: Matildas star Sam Kerr plays a key role in Chelsea's victory over Arsenal, as the club stands one game away from another title.

title.children: Sam Kerr stars again as Chelsea stands on the brink of a fourth straight Women's Super League title

image.altText: Brooks Koepka smiles and pumps his fist on the 18th green

items.synopsis: Brooks Koepka is a major champion again, winning the PGA Championship while new cult hero Michael Block produces a moment for the ages with a slam-dunk hole in one.

title.children: Koepka wins PGA Championship, but club pro Michael Block steals the show with incredible ace

image.altText: Zane Mellor in a pool reaches for the camera.

items.synopsis: The mother of a boy killed in the Hillcrest jumping castle tragedy says consultation over recovery efforts has been lacking – leaving her feeling the family has been "forgotten".

title.children: Georgie's son died in a jumping castle tragedy. Almost 18 months on, she says she feels 'forgotten'

image.altText: Team Ineos leads the peloton in the rain

items.synopsis: Torrential rain, freezing temperatures and a COVID-19 outbreak have turned this year's Giro d'Italia into a survival of the fittest. But 99 years ago, things were so much worse, with just eight finishers of the most brutal race in history..

title.children: The remarkable story of when eight riders finished the Giro d'Italia

image.altText: A 25-year-old woman with brown shoulder-length hair, large earring and formal clothes, sitting in a restaurant

items.synopsis: In her second feature, Petrol, Alena Lodkina delivers an original and uniquely Australian take on universal themes, proving why she is one of our most promising young directors.

title.children: This powerful film captures how some friendships can change you and others will nearly destroy you

image.altText: Travis Robinson stands in front of the large piles of washed salt

items.synopsis: Highly saline brine pumped from a deep aquifer on the Murray Darling Basin is being harvested for an essential mineral that has uses beyond the kitchen table.

title.children: Salt harvesters keep 200 tonnes a day from leaching into Murray River system

image.altText: A bright meteor falls from a starry sky. The image is captured on a grainy black and white camera.

items.synopsis: It's estimated the meteor was between half a metre to a metre in size and would have been travelling within 100,000 to 150,000 kilometres per hour.

title.children: 'The sky lit up — first white, then green': Astrophysicist confirms meteor sightings in Queensland

image.altText: A view of the outback from the window of a plane.

items.synopsis: There are calls for the federal government to make security funding for country airports more equitable after Rex Airlines cancelled its service in a regional South Australian city.

title.children: Calls to make airport charges fairer after Rex cancels Whyalla to Adelaide service

image.altText: Stan Grant David Anderson

items.synopsis: ABC managing director David Anderson apologises to Stan Grant and commits to a review into the ABC's response to racism affecting staff.

title.children: ABC's managing director apologises to Stan Grant after Q+A host steps away from role
